did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Virginia Secretary of the Commonwealth correspondence, 1891-1911
did.origination: Virginia. Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Virginia Secretary of the Commonwealth correspondence, 1891-1911. Accession 38174, State government records collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Transfer information is unavailable. Accessioned 6 June 2001.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth evolved from the position of the Secretary of the Colony during colonial times. Thomas Nelson held the position of the first Secretary of Virginia in 1776. Early Secretaries were elected by the public. An Act of the General Assembly in 1920 changed the election to a joint vote of the General Assembly. In a 1930 act of the General Assembly, the duties of the Secretary were redefined with the Secretary of the Commonwealth serving as the ex officio secretary of the Governor, as custodian of many official State records, and as keeper of the Greater and Lesser Seals of the Commonwealth. The office of the Secretary has gradually acquired other functions, such as: service of out-of-state civil process; appointment and regulation of notaries public; and registration and oversight of lobbyists. The Office became a gubernational appointment subsequent to a 1958 Act of the Assembly. The Secretary of the Commonwealth is under the jurisdiction of the Governor's Office and is appointed by the Governor for a term of four years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains incoming and outgoing correspondence of the Virginia Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth during the tenure of Secretaries J.T. Lawless and D.Q. Eggleston. Also included are letters to and from the clerk of the Secretary of the Commonwealth, J.G. Hankins.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series:

scopecontent.p: Contains the official correspondence of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. This series is divided into two subseries: General Correspondence and Subject Correspondence.
Contains requests for copies of state publications, business incorporation information, charters, and letters regarding various law-related topics.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by sender or recipient's last name and then chronologically within.

scopecontent.p: Contains letters to and from the Secretary of the Commonwealth which were grouped according to common topics such as automobile matters, appointments (the letters were originally addressed to Governor Andrew J. Montague), pardon requests (also addressed to Governor Montague), and notices of candidacy.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically and then chronologically within.

scopecontent.p: Contains the official and personal correspondence of the clerk to the Secretary of the Commonwealth, J.G. Hankins. Mr. Hankins served as clerk or in some capacity in the office of the secretary under Secretaries of the Commonwealth H.W. Flournoy, J.T. Lawless, and D.Q Eggleston. This series is divided into two subseries: General Correspondence and Subject Correspondence.

Contains a mixture of personal and official correspondence written to and from J.G. Hankins during his employment in the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. The business-related correspondence is very similar to the Secretary's general correspondence and contains mostly requests for legal information and publications. The personal correspondence includes letters pertaining to Hankins' attempt to become State Librarian, letters to and from family members, information about Masonic events, and invitations to weddings and graduations.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically and then chronologically within.

scopecontent.p: Contains letters to and from clerk J.G. Hankins that were grouped according to common topics such as Hankins' unsuccessful campaign to become Secretary of the Commonwealth in 1901, his candidacy for office in 1909, and various receipts.

did.unittitle: Candidacy for Secretary of the Commonwealth, 1909.
